contexts: Schopenhauer is often cited, as a fit subject for laughter, because he praised suicide while seated at a well-set table.
commentaries: The author references Schopenhauer as a thinker whose philosophical stance on suicide is often mocked for its perceived contradiction with his personal comforts.

raw.title: Wilhelm Meister
raw.author: Goethe
contexts: between Wilhelm Meister and Goethe’s maturity
commentaries: The author references Goethe's novel 'Wilhelm Meister' as an example of the relationship between an artist's global experience and the work that reflects it, suggesting a good relationship when the work is a facet of experience.

goodreads_match.title: Wilhelm Meister
goodreads_match.description: A masterpiece of German literature, this is the only edition in print in the English-speaking world of the complete Wilhelm Meister--both Wilhelm Meister's Years of Apprenticeshipand Wilhelm Meister's Years of TravelSpring had appeared in its full magnificence--an untimely storm that had been threatening all day broke turbulently on the heights, the rain moved over the countryside, the sun came out again in its radiance, and against the grey background the splendid rainbow became visible. Wilhelm was riding...

raw.author: Plotinus
contexts: Since Plotinus, who was the first to reconcile it with the eternal climate, it has learned to turn away from the most cherished of its principles, which is contradiction, in order to integrate into it the strangest, the quite magic one of participation.
With Plotinus, after being logical it becomes æsthetic. Metaphor takes the place of the syllogism.
This whole attitude is already contained in the concept so dear to the Alexandrian thinker that there is not only an idea of man but also an idea of Socrates.
The same, in truth, that is found in Proust’s work or in the landscape of Plotinus: a nostalgia for a lost paradise.
Is there anything odd in finding on earth that union that Plotinus longed for?
commentaries: The author references Plotinus as a historical figure whose philosophical work reconciled reason with the eternal, illustrating a shift in how reason operates.
The author discusses Plotinus in the context of the adaptation of reason, noting a shift from logic to aesthetics in his thought, which is presented as a historical development.
The author attributes a specific philosophical concept to Plotinus, highlighting his contribution to phenomenology through the idea of individual forms.
The author references Plotinus's landscape as an example of a work containing a melancholy nostalgia for a lost paradise, similar to that found in Kafka's work.
The author references Plotinus as a philosopher who longed for a spiritual union, using this as a point of comparison for the earthly unity found in the Algerian landscape.

raw.author: Karl Jaspers
contexts: When Karl Jaspers, revealing the impossibility of constituting the world as a unity, exclaims: “This limitation leads me to myself, where I can no longer withdraw behind an objective point of view that I am merely representing, where neither I myself nor the existence of others can any longer become an object for me,” he is evoking after many others those waterless deserts where thought reaches its confines.
But Jaspers will provide us, in caricatural form, a typical example of this attitude.
And paradoxically can be understood Jaspers’s insistence, his infinite patience devoted to making the experience of the transcendent impossible to realize.
commentaries: The author quotes Jaspers to illustrate a philosophical position on the limits of objective thought and the confrontation with the self, placing him in a tradition of thinkers who have reached similar conceptual boundaries.
The author references Jaspers as a philosopher who exemplifies an existential attitude of escape, deifying the absurd to find hope.
The author references Jaspers's philosophical approach, noting his insistence and patience in demonstrating the impossibility of realizing the transcendent.

raw.author: Husserl
contexts: Husserl’s manner of proceeding, in the beginning, nevertheless negates the classic method of the reason
I shall examine merely the theme of “the Intention” made fashionable by Husserl and the phenomenologists.

I am not examining the philosophy of Kierkegaard or of Chestov or, later on, of Husserl (this would call for a different place and a different attitude of mind); I am simply borrowing a theme from them and examining whether its consequences can fit the already established rules.
commentaries: The author discusses Husserl's philosophical method, noting its initial negation of classical reason and its opening to intuition, placing him in dialogue with other existential thinkers.
The author mentions Husserl and phenomenologists in the context of examining the theme of 'the Intention'.
The author notes Husserl as a philosopher whose themes are being utilized, albeit without a full philosophical examination, suggesting a selective engagement with his ideas.

contexts: "Prayer," says Alain, "is when night descends over thought."
commentaries: The author cites Alain's definition of prayer as a point of departure for discussing the encounter of the mind with night, contrasting it with the mystics' and existentialists' views.

raw.author: Heraclitus
contexts: At the dawn of Greek thought Heraclitus was already imagining that justice sets limits for the physical universe itself : “The sun will not overstep his measures; if he does, the Erinyes, the handmaids of justice, will find him out.”
A fragment attributed to the same Heraclitus simply states: “Presumption, regression of progress.”
commentaries: The author quotes Heraclitus to illustrate the Greek concept of limits and justice, using his philosophical idea as a foundational example.
The author references a fragment by Heraclitus to illustrate the concept of presumption as a regression of progress.

raw.author: Molière
contexts: At this point I am thinking of Molière’s Alceste.
I measure the greatness of an artist (Molière, Tolstoy, Melville) by the balance he managed to maintain between the two.
commentaries: The author references Molière as the creator of the character Alceste, using the play as an example of a nature carried to its extreme, illustrating the absurd consequence within the work.
The author cites Molière as an example of a great artist who balanced artistic creation with human values.

raw.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
contexts: from Nietzsche that one must maltreat one’s mother.
Of course, like Nietzsche, the most famous of God’s assassins, he ends in madness.
And if it is true, as Nietzsche claims, that a philosopher, to deserve our respect, must preach by example, you can appreciate the importance of that reply, for it will precede the definitive act.
if I accept the Nietzschean criterion

When Nietzsche writes: "It clearly seems that the chief thing in heaven and on earth is to obey at length and in a single direction: in the long run there results something for which it is worth the trouble of living on this earth as, for example, virtue, art, music, the dance, reason, the mind—something that transfigures, something delicate, mad, or divine," he elucidates the rule of a really distinguished code of ethics.
“What matters,” said Nietzsche, “is not eternal life but eternal vivacity.”
"Art and nothing but art," said Nietzsche; "we have art in order not to die of the truth."
For Kirilov, as for Nietzsche, to kill God is to become god oneself; it is to realize on this earth the eternal life of which the Gospel speaks.
It seems that we are witnessing here an interminable exploitation of Nietzsche’s remark: “Great problems are in the street.”
This is perhaps the secret of that proud aridity felt in Nietzsche’s work.
Nietzsche is outdistanced.
commentaries: The author references Nietzsche to caution against literal interpretations of philosophical ideas within the absurd framework.
The author mentions Nietzsche as a philosophical figure (a 'God’s assassin') whose ideas parallel the character Ivan Karamazov's trajectory into madness.
The author references Nietzsche's idea about philosophers leading by example to underscore the seriousness of the philosophical problem of suicide.
The author references Nietzsche's philosophical criterion as a standard for evaluating whether individuals implicitly affirm life despite their stated denials.
The author quotes Nietzsche to illustrate a rule of a distinguished code of ethics and points out that this also shows the way of the absurd man.
The author cites Nietzsche's statement to contrast the pursuit of eternal vivacity with the desire for eternal life, aligning with the theme of the absurd.
The author quotes Nietzsche to support the idea that art is a vital response to the harshness of truth, positioning it as an absurd joy and a means of survival.
The author draws a parallel between Kirilov's philosophy and Nietzsche's idea of killing God to become a god, citing Nietzsche as a source of similar ideas.
The author references Nietzsche as the source of a remark about profound issues being found in ordinary life, using it to frame the analysis of Kafka's work.
The author references Nietzsche's work as exemplifying a proud aridity derived from an aesthetic of the Absurd, characterized by sterile lucidity and a negation of supernatural consolation.
The author references Nietzsche to indicate that contemporary events have surpassed his philosophical critiques, particularly regarding violence and excess.

raw.author: Aristotle
contexts: Over the centuries no one has furnished a clearer and more elegant demonstration of the business than Aristotle: “The often ridiculed consequence of these opinions is that they destroy themselves.
Apropos of the notion of exception particularly and against Aristotle.
commentaries: The author cites Aristotle as a historical philosophical authority to support the point that self-reflective thought leads to contradiction.
The author briefly references Aristotle in opposition to a notion of exception, indicating a critical engagement with Aristotelian thought within the argument.

raw.title: The Trial
raw.author: Franz Kafka
contexts: In The Trial, Joseph K. is accused.
the works of Kafka can quite as legitimately be interpreted in the sense of a social criticism (for instance in The Trial).
B. Groethuysen in his remarkable preface to The Trial limits himself, more wisely than we, to following merely the painful fancies of what he calls, most strikingly, a daydreamer.
commentaries: The author uses Kafka's novel as a primary example to analyze the naturalness and symbolic structure of Kafka's work, discussing the protagonist's uncomprehending acceptance of his absurd situation.
The author cites the novel as an example where Kafka's work can be interpreted as social criticism, while also acknowledging its metaphysical revolt.
The author references Groethuysen's preface to the novel as an example of an aesthetic interpretation that focuses on the work's dreamlike qualities without seeking confirmation.

goodreads_match.title: The Trial
goodreads_match.description: A terrifying psychological trip into the life of one Joseph K., an ordinary man who wakes up one day to find himself accused of a crime he did not commit, a crime whose nature is never revealed to him. Once arrested, he is released, but must report to court on a regular basis - an event that proves maddening, as nothing is ever resolved. As he grows more uncertain of his fate, his personal life - including work at a bank and his relations with his landlady and a young woman who lives next door - becomes inc...

raw.author: Sophocles
contexts: Thus, Œdipus at the outset obeys fate without knowing it. But from the moment he knows, his tragedy begins. Yet at the same moment, blind and desperate, he realizes that the only bond linking him to the world is the cool hand of a girl. Then a tremendous remark rings out: “Despite so many ordeals, my advanced age and the nobility of my soul make me conclude that all is well.” Sophocles’ Œdipus, like Dostoevsky’s Kirilov, thus gives the recipe for the absurd victory.
commentaries: The author references Sophocles' character Oedipus as a literary example of one who achieves an absurd victory by acknowledging his fate and concluding 'all is well.'

raw.author: Bergson
contexts: Consciousness does not form the object of its understanding, it merely focuses, it is the act of attention, and, to borrow a Bergsonian image, it resembles the projector that suddenly focuses on an image.
commentaries: The author borrows an image from Bergson to illustrate the nature of consciousness in phenomenology.

raw.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
contexts: "Everything is permitted," exclaims Ivan Karamazov.
Thus the novels, like the Diary, propound the absurd question.
For instance, Balzac, Sade, Melville, Stendhal, Dostoevsky, Proust, Malraux, Kafka, to cite but a few.
Yet it is he who speaks calmly of his divinity. He is not mad, or else Dostoevsky is.
Sophocles’ Œdipus, like Dostoevsky’s Kirilov, thus gives the recipe for the absurd victory.
Landscapes are not to be found in great European literature since Dostoevsky.

Like Dostoevsky’s fools who boast of everything, soar to heaven, and end up flaunting their shame in any public place, we merely lack man’s pride, which is fidelity to his limits, lucid love of his condition.
commentaries: The author references Ivan Karamazov's statement to illustrate a point about the absurd, noting its bitter acknowledgment rather than joyful liberation.
The author references Dostoevsky's body of work (his novels and 'Diary') collectively as sources that pose the absurd question.
The author lists Dostoevsky among great philosophical novelists who write in images rather than reasoned arguments, highlighting a common thought about the uselessness of explanatory principles.

The author references Dostoevsky as the creator of the character Kirilov, implying that if Kirilov's claims are not madness, then Dostoevsky himself might be considered mad, thus engaging with Dostoevsky's literary work.
The author cites Dostoevsky's character Kirilov, from his novel 'The Possessed,' as a parallel to Oedipus in demonstrating the recipe for an absurd victory.
The author cites Dostoevsky as a benchmark in European literature, noting the absence of natural landscapes in works after him.
The author references Dostoevsky's characters as archetypes of foolishness and lack of pride, using them to critique the modern era's condition.

raw.title: Hamlet

contexts: “And blest are those,” says Hamlet, “whose blood and judgment are so well commingled that they are not a pipe for fortune’s finger to sound what stop she please.”
commentaries: The author quotes a line from Shakespeare's character Hamlet to illustrate a point about the integration of passion and reason.

goodreads_match.title: Hamlet
goodreads_match.description: One of the greatest plays of all time, the compelling tragedy of the tormented young prince of Denmark continues to capture the imaginations of modern audiences worldwide. Confronted with evidence that his uncle murdered his father, and with his mother's infidelity, Hamlet must find a means of reconciling his longing for oblivion with his duty as avenger. The ghost, Hamlet's feigned madness, Ophelia's death and burial, the play within a play, the "closet scene" in which Hamlet accuses his mother of complici...

raw.author: Proust
contexts: The groping, anxious quest of a Proust, his meticulous collecting of flowers, of wallpapers, and of anxieties, signifies nothing else.
For instance, Balzac, Sade, Melville, Stendhal, Dostoevsky, Proust, Malraux, Kafka, to cite but a few.
commentaries: The author references Proust's literary method as an example of the absurd creative process, where meticulous observation and collection represent living doubly and fixing consciousness.
The author lists Proust among great philosophical novelists who write in images rather than reasoned arguments, highlighting a common thought about the uselessness of explanatory principles.
